  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal NBM experienced a UN3267 Chem-Aqua 18106 release from a 55-gallon poly drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 50-gallons of product released to a 23' x 8' area of the trailer floor and a 15' x 8' area of the concrete lot below. The drum was damaged due to a broken pallet. The impacted areas were cleaned and neutralized with absorbents and collected into (2) 55-gallon poly drums. The damaged drum of product was placed into an 85-gallon poly overpack. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal NBM experienced a UN1789 Hydrochloric Acid release from a 250-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1 cup of product released to an 8 x 4 area of the wood trailer floor due to a loose cap. The cap was secured and the tote was wiped down for continued shipment. The impacted area was then cleaned with soda ash to neutralize the release. All impacted soda ash, PPE, and poly sheeting were collected into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately five (5) ounces released into the shrink-wrap from one (1) 55-gallon metal drum containing DT STYPOL 040-4332. Personnel advised the drum sustained a dent in the back due to damage from the trailer wall, which caused a small hole and was the cause of the release. Dayton Freight advised they no surfaces were impacted since release was contained to shrink-wrap. The terminal personnel stated they overpacked the drum and the shrink wrap and generated one (1) 85-gallon metal drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freights contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from GrayMar Environmental Services (GES) to remediate the site. GES personnel deployed granular absorbents to the Tetraethyl Silicate-impacted trailer and dock and worked them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum and the 55-gallon drum of Tetraethyl Silicate was containerized in one (1) 95-gallon over-pack.

  • City: HOUSTON

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On November 11, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of Dichloromethane was punctured in transit and released approximately three (3) gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement underneath the trailer. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from E3 Environmental (E3) to remediate the site. E3 personnel deployed granular absorbents to the Dichloromethane-impacted trailer and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents and one (1) broken-down impacted pallet were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum, and one (1) 55-gallon drum of Dichloromethane was containerized in one (1) 85-gallon over-pack drum.

  • Description: On NOvember 6, 2024, one (1) tote of paint leaked approximately less than one (<1) gallon of product to the outside of the tote. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Alpha Omega Training and Compliance (AOTC) to remediate the site. Crews observed paint residue that had hardened on the top of the tote. AOTC crews scraped the paint from the tote utilizing hand tools. AOTC wiped down the area and containerized the paint residue and impacted debris into one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024110341
item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-21T12:39:47+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-22
  • City: CAMDEN
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CONSOLIDATED RAIL CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On Tuesday, 10/22/2024 at approximately 11:30 a train crew reported UTLX 202686 leaking from the top of the tank car. UTLX 202686 was a loaded tank car of Acetone from the Advansix Plant in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Conrail Hazardous Material Manager, Joe Caaccamo was in the yard and responded to inspect the tank car. Upon inspection liquid was visible coming from the breadbox seal number ADVANSIX 074737 was intact on the breadbox. The seal was removed and the liquid line was found in the open position well as the secondary securement plug less than tool tight. Once the valve was placed in the closed position the leak stopped entirely. The secondary securement plug was properly secured and all material was dissipating/evaporating from the tank car. Seal number ULINE 1202402 was placed on the breadbox. The tank car was ppaced to be inspected prior to release pending OTMA the following day with no leak detected on 10/23/2024. Tank car UTLX 202686 is still pending OTMA in the Pavonia Terminal. Jeff Matlack with Advansix (267) 319-6382 was informed of the situation and advised OTMA is required.

From there we dispatched (2) additional trucks from Granite City IL to remove the contents from the trailer. At appox 0500 on Oct 22nd all ammonia was removed from the leaking trailer. The trailer was then transported to our maintenance vendor. They entered the tank and saw that a baffle had broken inside the tank and rested against the PRV and bending it causing it leak.

  • Description: On 10/9/2024 at around 12:00, CPKC Hazmat was made aware by FRA Inspector Vincent Leishman that NATX 37675 had been found Ieaking from the bottom outlet valve secondary closure cap during a hazmat inspection. CPKC mobilized a railroad qualified response contractor to investigate and mitigate the release. Upon arrival, responders actuated the bottom outlet valve in an attempt to secure it prior to removing the bottom outlet valve(BOV) cap. While removing the BOV cap, responders discovered that it was less than tool tight. Additionally, responders noticed that Methanol was Ieaking past the bottom outlet ball and seal. A new gasket was installed in the BOV cap. The BOV cap was then secured tool tight, stopping the release. File Note: Item 19-the quantity released was estimated based on the best information available at the time of filing. This shipment was offered as a'bulk' shipment, aka one car load, therefore the exact amount offered in this package is not known to the carrier. This carrier does not have access to mass balance data which can exactly quantify this value.

item.title: Report I-2024110038
item.description:
Report I-2024110038

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-21T12:39:47+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-08
  • City: SAINT PAUL
  • State: MN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: SOO LINE RAILROAD COMPANY(DBA CANADIAN PACIFIC KANSAS CITY RAILROAD)
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 10000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 10/8/2024 at 12:15 PM, CPKC Hazmat became aware that residue SODIUM CHLORATE hopper car, OFOX 60804, was Ieaking while in the ST Paul, MN rail yard. A rail qualified response contractor was mobilized to investigate and mitigate the release. Upon arrival, OFOX 60804 was found to be Ieaking from the A end hopper on the left side at the bottom camlock cap fitting. The A end hopper was found to have less than 1/8 of a compartment of liquid and solid solution. OFOX 60804 was also found to be Ieaking from the B end hopper on the left side where the bottom of the hopper is fastened to the frame of the car. The B end hopper was found with over 1/2 of a compartment of liquid and solid solution. It appeared that the shipper failed to fully unload the hoppers before releasing the car into transportation. Estimated release from the A end hopper is 9 gallons. Estimated release from the B end hopper is 1 gallon. Responders stopped the release from the A end hopper by securing a nitrile glove over the camlock cap fitting and the loading/unloading line with duct tape and a tension strap. Containment was placed under the point of release emanating from the B end hopper and sealant was applied to the seam where the bottom of the hopper is fastened to the frame of the car to stop the leak. The source of the B end hopper release was.inside the hopper and could not be accessed. The contents of OFOX 60804 were transferred Into a tank truck, and then the hoppers were rinsed with water. The root defect was not determined for the A end bottom camlock cap fitting, though it was thought to have been attributable to a loose component. Likewise, the source of the release on the B end was not determined because it was not visible; however, due to the nature of the commodity moved in this specialized hopper car, it is likely to be attributableto a failure in a weld or seam within the hopper. File Note: Item 19-the quantity released was estimated based on the best info,iation available at the time of filing. This shipment was offered as a'bulk' shipment, aka one car load, therefore the exact amount offered in this package is not known to the carrier. This carrier does not have access to mass balance data which can exactly quantify this value.

item.title: Report I-2024110043
item.description:
Report I-2024110043

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-20T12:31:13+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-11-05
  • City: DALLAS
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED AIRLINES HOLDINGS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: During the flight the AFT Iav smoke detector went off. The FA's knocked on the door and the passenger in the Iav did not want to open the door at first immediately. She open the door and claimed her laptop(which was with her in the Iav) had started smoking. The Laptop was placed in TCB as a precaution, the passenger did not want to relinquish her laptop at first. FA's did not witness any smoke coming from the laptop; it is suspected the passenger may have been vaping in the Iav in actuality and that, that is how the smoke detector was activated. Upon landing, the passenger did not want to deplane without her laptop. The Passenger claimed United was stealing it from her. Police had to be called.

item.title: Report X-2024110648
item.description:
Report X-2024110648

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-20T12:31:13+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-11-03
  • City: EVERETT
  • State: WA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: BNSF Railway Company
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 20000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Tank car GATX 109865 was reported to be leaking with visible vapor release and icing on the protective housing while in the BNSF Everett Delta yard. The car was isolated and responders were mobilized to inspect. Upon inspection, it was found that the sample line valve was cracked near the threads to the sample line nipple. A Midland kit was installed to control the release. GATX 109865 was transferred to the FURX 130095. The cracked sample valve was removed from the car and a cap installed to secure the car for movement under an OTMA to shop for repairs. Release estimates are based upon evaluation of outage at the time of the response in comparison to original outage. All released Butane dissipated to atmosphere.

item.title: Report E-2024100729
item.description:
Report E-2024100729

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-20T12:31:13+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-03
  • City: Phoenix
  • State: AZ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: CANYON STATE PROPANE, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 244740
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Jesse Marquez-Zamora was traveling northbound on freeway 101 at 50 mph on 10-3-2024 at approximately 820am. The vehicle traveling in front of Jesse proceeded to heavy brake. Jesse then proceeded to apply his brakes, but it was not enough to stop his propane bobtail. Jesse then attempted to maneuver around the vehicle in front of him to the left, this was when Jesse lost control of the truck. Jesse's truck then proceeded to hit the vehicle in front of him and rolled 2 times, there were a total of 4 vehicles involved. During the rollover a piped valve was knocked off causing the release of approximately 2240 gallons of propane. Jesse and another individual were taken to the ER for evaluation then released

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 12500
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On October 3,2024 EJ Pope made a delivery to Pop's Fuel. A minor spill was reported by the driver. On October 8,2024, EJ Pope was notified that a larger release had occurred. First Call Environmental was dispatched to inspect the area and perform the required cleanup. First Call Environmental responded and inspected the site. First Call Environmental confirmed that no waterways were affected by the release, however some impacted soil was located. Completion of site cleanup is pending.

item.description:

  • Description: THREE AIR PACKAGES WERE INSPECTED DUE TO A RECENT UNDECLARED DANGEROUS GOODS PACKAGE BEING FOUND FROM THE ACCOUNT HOLDER. UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED TRACKING NUMBER 1ZJ5H5581211826870 CONTAINS FOUR X 1-GALLON CONTAINERS OF FLAMMABLE CLASSIC EXPRESS STAIN. TRACKING NUMBER 1ZJ5H5581227456188 CONTAINS SIX X 1-QUART CONTAINERS OF FLAMMABLE CLASSIC EXPRESS STAIN. TRACKING NUMBER 1ZJ5H5581211001868 CONTAINS TWENTY-FOUR X 1-QUART CONTAINERS OF FLAMMABLE EXPRESS STAIN. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOXES. THESE PACKAGES HAVE NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO. THESE PACKAGES WERE SHIPPED FROM SOUTH CAROLINA USING UPS ACCOUNT NUMBER J5H558, WHITE, 4115 DORCHESTER RD, NORTH CHARLESTON SC 29405-7466. SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT BEING SUBMITTED TO CORRECT PART VI- DESCRIPTION OF EVENTS AND PACKAGE FAILURE TO CORRECTLY DESCRIBE QUANTITIES CONTAINED IN EACH PACKAGE. 5800.1 ORIGINALLY SUBMITTED AND ACCEPTED ON 12/SEPT/2024, PHMSA TRACKING NUMBER 908299. PHMSA REPORT NUMBER X-2024090842.

  • Description: Operations Supervisor at service center 064 contacted Safety regarding a slow leak from one of the corners of a tote containing corrosive liquid that spilled on the trailer and dock floor. The operations supervisor advised the tote did not appear to be punctured. The tote was briefly moved to the do ck, but when it continued to leak it was moved back to the trailer to contain the leak. Brandon Baumann with CURA advised the cleaning crew discovered the tote to be leaking from a defective valve.

  • Description: DURING SCREENING PROCESS OF A PREBUILT UNIT (PBU) ULD AAY11427UPS OFFERED TO UPS AIR CARGO SERVICES IN MIAMI, FLORIDA GOING TO COLOMBIA, WE DISCOVERED TWENTY-THREE BOXES LOADED INSIDE WITH FULLY AND PARTIALLY COVERED LITHIUM BATTERY MARKS. UPON FURTHER INSPECTION, A TOTAL OF NINETY SONY WIRELESS CONTROLLERS WERE FOUND INSIDE THOSE FULLY AND PARTIALLY COVERED PACKAGES. THE UNIT WAS OFFERED TO UPS BY SHIP CARGO CORP ON BEHALF OF ZENDERBOX CARGO INC. DANGEROUS GOODS ARE PROHIBITED IN ALL PREBUILT UNITS. AN INVESTIGATION WITH THE SHIPPER IS ONGOING.

item.title: Report X-2024110505
item.description:
Report X-2024110505

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-19T12:23:44+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-24
  • City: HARAHAN
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Illinois Central Railroad Company
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 18091
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 10-24-2024 at approximately 07:00 AM a CN transportation employee observed a white vapor emitting from the top of tank car # RCRX 2542 (residue/UN 1789/Class 8/PGII) while performing switching operations at the CN Mays Yard in Harahan, LA. The car was set out to an isolation track. All departments were notified leading to an emergency response from a CN Dangerous Goods Team contractor. The responding contractor observed a small amount of liquid (PH tested ?1?) within the protective housing. All securement nuts on the air and liquid valve were verified to be tool tight. There was no obvious point of the leak during the initial inspection. The tank car was pressurized with dry air to 10 psi for the purpose of identifying the exact origin of the leak. The pressure test revealed a minuscule leak emanating from the spool of the liquid eduction line through what appeared to be a pin sized hole. The tank car was completely de-pressurized through a scrubbing media. The pinhole on the spool was wrapped with chemical tape to prevent any further leakage. The car owner was notified of the findings and will send a qualified mobile repair unit out to replace the spool and re-qualify the tank car. 10-31-2024 the tank car owner performed an assessment of the tank car. Below is their findings: Technicians from our Saint Gabreil, LA certified shop responded to RCRX 2542 on 10/31/2024. Upon arrival, the technician's initial inspection found product residue inside the protective housing. In addition, there appeared to be no gasket present below the product blind flange which was confirmed after removing the blind flange. A product gasket was applied and secured. The car was then pressurized to 30 psi and a certified leak test was performed to all fittings and connections with no leaks found. The residue product was rinsed off of the fittings and side of car. Security seals were applied as well to the fittings.

item.title: Report E-2024110328
item.description:
Report E-2024110328

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-19T12:23:44+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-15
  • City: Anchorage
  • State: AK
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: LYNDEN AIR CARGO, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Aircraft landed at Ralph Wien Memorial Airport in Kotzebue Alaska. After the offload, the Loadmaster walked the freight slated for upload. Lynden Air Cargo's ground handler FBX handles multiple different air carriers, and consolidated freight from three different customers. In which two of the customers freight was slated for another air carrier mixed in with the scheduled freight for Lynden Air Cargo. The Loadmaster failed to recognize the additional cargo and therefore did not notice the additional hazardous materials. The consolidated cargo was then loaded and then flown back to Ted Stevens Anchorage Airport to Lynden Air Cargo's facility. On September 18th Lynden Air Cargo was getting the shipment ready to be transported over the road to the one customer that was the only shipper we were aware of. During that phase the extra hazmat and pieces were identified, and an internal investigation ensued.

In which two of the customers freight was slated for another air carrier mixed in with the scheduled freight for Lynden Air Cargo. The Loadmaster failed to recognize the additional cargo and therefore did not notice the additional hazardous materials. The consolidated cargo was then loaded and then flown back to Ted Stevens Anchorage Airport to Lynden Air Cargo's facility. On September 18th Lynden Air Cargo was getting the shipment ready to be transported over the road to the one customer that was the only shipper we were aware of. During that phase the extra hazmat and pieces were identified, and an internal investigation ensued. 3. E-2024110327 Aircraft landed at Ralph Wien Memorial Airport in Kotzebue Alaska. After the offload, the Loadmaster walked the freight slated for upload. Lynden Air Cargo's ground handler FBX handles multiple different air carriers, and consolidated freight from three different customers. In which two of the customers freight was slated for another air carrier mixed in with the scheduled freight for Lynden Air Cargo. The Loadmaster failed to recognize the additional cargo and therefore did not notice the additional hazardous materials. The consolidated cargo was then loaded and then flown back to Ted Stevens Anchorage Airport to Lynden Air Cargo's facility. On September 18th Lynden Air Cargo was getting the shipment ready to be transported over the road to the one customer that was the only shipper we were aware of. During that phase the extra hazmat and pieces were identified, and an internal investigation ensued.

item.description:
Report E-2024110317

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-18T12:24:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-11-15
  • City: CLACKAMAS
  • State: OR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal UPO experienced a UN2922 P&S Wire Wheel and Tire Cleaner release from a box containing (4) 1-gallon poly jugs. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1-cup of product released to a 2 x 2 area of the dock and trailer floor due to improper loading. The damaged jugs were placed into a 55-gallon poly drum. Absorbents, pads, and neutralizer were then used to clean the impacted area. All cleanup debris, cardboard, and PPE were placed into a second 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2024110322
item.description:
Report E-2024110322

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-18T12:24:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-11-13
  • City: COLOGNE
  • State:
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AT THE UPS FACILITY IN COLOGNE, GERMANY (CGN), DURING LOADING OF AN AIR CONTAINER DESTINED FOR SPAIN (MAD), AN AIR PACKAGE FROM HONG KONG TO SPAIN WAS FOUND EMITTING SMOKE AND FUMES. A STRONG SMELL WAS RECOGNIZED IN THE CONTAINER INITIATING UNLOADING OF THE CONTAINER TO FIND THE EVENT PACKAGE. ONCE FOUND THE PACKAGE WAS IMMEDIATELY REMOVED FROM THE BUILDING AND SUNK IN A BARREL OF WATER TO STOP THE LITHIUM BATTERY EVENT. THE INCIDENT PACKAGE WAS MARKED AND LABELLED AS UN3480, LITHIUM ION BATTERIES, SECTION IA OF PACKING INSTRUCTION 965 WITH A CAO AND CLASS 9 LITHIUM BATTERY LABEL. THE PACKAGE WAS PART OF A MULTIPLE TEN PACKAGE SHIPMENT WITH AN APPROPRIATE IATA SHIPPERS DECLARATION AND HAD PREVIOUSLY PASSED AN ACCEPTANCE AUDIT IN HONG KONG. PRIOR TO THE LITHIUM BATTERY EVENT IN COLOGNE, GERMANY, THE PACKAGE HAD PREVIOUSLY FLOWN ON UPS AIRCRAFT FROM HKG - DXB - CGN. THE PACKAGE WAS REPORTED TO THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER ON 14-NOVEMBER-2024, REPORT NUMBER 1416362.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XRC experienced a UN2680 Lithium Hydroxide Monohydrate release from a 50-pound poly bag. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2 cups of product released to a 4 x 3 area of the concrete dock floor. The bag was ripped as a result of improper loading. The damaged bag and cleanup debris were collected and containerized into a 15-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Incident Date: 2024-11-06
  • City: BUTLER
  • State: IN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: PVS STEEL SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On November 6, 2024, a spill incident occurred at the Heidtman Butler facility involving an overfill of a tanker truck. During a product transfer operation, the driver failed to actively monitor the flow from the dome of the tanker truck, which is required to prevent overflow. Instead, the driver was standing at the back of the trailer, timing the transfer rather than visually overseeing the product flow from the dome. As a result, approximately 300 gallons of ferrous chloride solution (372 pounds) overflowed from the tanker, spilling onto the facilitys limestone gravel bed.

item.title: Report E-2024110122
item.description:
Report E-2024110122

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-18T12:24:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-17
  • City: MILFORD
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: WORLD FUEL SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 7081
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 10/18/2024, a World Fuel Service, Inc. (WFS) transport driver when starting their shift at 04:30 called the HSE Manager to report a spill at the WFS Milford Bulk Plant. They reported there was diesel spilled throughout the facility yard and onto US HWY 50. The transport driver did know who caused it. They provided pictures and was allowed to start their shift. The HSE Manager and Milford Operations Manager went to the site to further investigate the release and its severity. After arriving to the Milford yard it was clear that someone had loaded a tank wagon and spilled product without notifying anyone. The HSE Manager and Operations Manager looked at unit 865 and it was clear the truck had an overfill and product had spilled over top of it. Th truck had fuel staining on the tanker and on the front/back of the it. HSE and Operations spoke with both night drivers and confirmed who used unit 865. When speaking with driver that used 865, they stated that they did not know about or caused any spill. The driver had started their shift at 17:30 on 10/17/2024. Footage was pulled from the truck camera system in order to determine the cause of the release. Camera footage showed the driver loading from 06:00 pm to around 06:35 pm. Camera footage showed the driver causing a spill of diesel from the truck after loading. It showed the driver pulling out of the loading bay and then back in the loading bay spilling product. Next, the driver gets out to look at the truck top, then gets back in the truck and backs out of loading bay and pulls around circling in the yard. Then, parks 10 feet away from a storm drain at the facility while product is still being released to the ground from the truck top. Next, the driver gets out and looks at the spill. During this time the driver does not take any action to stop or slow the spill nor did they report it to HSE or Operations. The driver was not following procedures and neglected to take any actions addressing the spill. Finally, the driver walks into the office building, comes back out and proceeds to leave the yard. When doing so more diesel is spilled. The majority of diesel is spilled in the facility yard. The driver turns right (west) onto US HWY 50. Product splashes off the truck onto the road way for several hundred yards. The driver finished his shift, returned to the yard and parked the truck back at the Milford Facility without reporting the release. Approximately 30 gallons of diesel fuel was spilled. HEPACO was contacted on 10/18/2024 at 04:57 and was dispatched to clean up the spill. One storm drain was impacted at the WFS facility and the diesel fuel was contained to the catch basin and recovered. Weather conditions were dry and there was no precipitation. On 10/18/2024 between 07:56 and 12:31 the NRC, Ohio EPA, Clermont Co. EMA, and Miami TWP Fire Dept. were notified of the spilled. Diesel that spilled on to US HWY 50 was not cleaned up and no roadway safety issues were reported. HEPACO finished the

  • Description: At 1242 ET, Jed Burga with XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at terminal XUR. It was reported that an unknown amount of UN3253 released from paper bags due to improper shipper loading. The release impacted Dock 3. No storm drains or waterways are reported to be impacted by the release. A contractor was dispatched and observed eight torn bags that released approximately 1-cup of product onto the concrete dock floor, adjacent product, and plastic shrink-wrap. The concrete dock floor was impacted in a 1x1 area. The product was damaged due to improper loading by the Shipper. The contractor overpacked the damaged bag, containerized the floor sweepings of product and the impacted shrink-wrap. In total, five drums of waste were generated that were staged on-site for XPO to manage.

  • Description: Chris Lawrence Operations Supervisor called safety to report a spill in trailer 500859, UN1263, PAINT, 3, PG II. Chris stated while the forklift was unloading a pallet that was stacked on the pallet of UN1263, PAINT, the pallet pulled the lid off one of the 5-gallon pails of paint causing 20oz of th e paint to spill on the trailer floor and other freight. Chris stated it looked like the pallet that was on top was to heavy and damaged the pail and the lid and when the forklift removed the pallet it pulled the damaged lid causing the spill. Chris stated he stopped work and called safety to report the spill and to send photos. Chris stated he will stop work on the trailer until the cleaning crew arrives to clean the spill in the trailer and the other freight. Chris stated the spill was contained to the trailer.

  • Description: While doing a warehouse inventory, cargo agent noticed a DGR pc of cargo looked wet. He contacted a supervisor for further Investigation. This pe was on top of a skid containing additional pcs of the awb. Upon removing this po from the top of the skid it was noticed that it was toxic. The area was roped off and the import file was obtained, the 24 hour emergency contact number (Chemtrek) was called. Agent fowarded the Safety Data Sheet. We were told to follow rule 6 and 7 which allowed us to place the fiberboard box into a salvage container using protective equipment. The box itself was not noticably leaking but did appear wet. Absorbant material was first placed into the container, then the box, then more abosorbant material.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XLM experienced a customer location release from a 55-gallon poly drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to site to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 20-gallons of product released to a 4 x 2 area of the trailer floor and a 25 x 15 area of the asphalt lot below. The drum appeared to be crushed or punctured by the pallet, causing the release. The damaged drum was placed into an 85-gallon poly overpack. Absorbents and vinegar were deployed to clean and neutralize the impacted areas. All impacted absorbents and debris were containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was transported to XPO for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: A fiberboard box with an odor was presented to the MEMH spill office. While investigating the shipment the agent found that the bottom chime of the metal can inside was damaged causing a release. The can was packaged in a plastic bag with a fiberboard divider and a empty can for dunnage. It was placed into a steel salvage package and the shipper will be contacted for an amended declaration for movement.

  • City: WILMINGTON
  • State: OH

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On November 5, 2024, oen (1) 5-gallon pail of UN3266 was damaged in transit and released approximately two (2) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. TLE personnel utilized hand tools, absorbents, and soda ash to remediate the UN3266-impacted impacted dock floor. The damaged pail and all impacted debris were collected and containerized into two (2) 35-gallon lined poly drums for disposal.

  • City: LENEXA

  • Description: 1. X-2024110520 SUPERVISOR CALLED IN A LEAKER TO THE DMP AND DMP DISPATCHED A RESPONDER WITH FULL PPE AND SPILL CART. RESPONDER ARRIVED ON SCENE AND FOUND THE LEAKING PACKAGE. RESPONDER FOLLOWED THE DECSION TREE GUIDLINES AND WENT TO RESPONSE SHEET SEVEN. RESPONDER FOLLOWED CLEAN UP PROCEDURE AND BROUGHT THE LEAKER BACK TO THE DMP FOR PROPER DISPOSAL. PACKAGE WAS PROPERLY DISPOSED OF. 2. X-2024110521 LEAKER WAS CALLED INTO THE DMP AND DMP DISPATCHED A RESPONDER WITH FULL PPE AND SPILL CART TO DOOR 22. RESPONDER ARRIVED ON SCENE AND FOUND THE LEAKER AND USED THE DECSION TREE TO FIND CORRECT RESPONSE SHEET. RESPONDER USED THE FLAMMABLE LIQUID RESPONSE SHEET TO CLEAN UP THE SPILL AND BRING BACK THE LEAKER TO DMP FOR PROPER DISPOSAL. LEAKER WAS PROPERLY DISPOSED OF.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately four (4) gallons of product released from four (4) one (1) gallon jerricans impacting the dock floor. Personnel advised the release was due to shifting while in transit. Dayton Freight personnel cleaned release using floor dri absorbent, the team confirmed they generated one (1) 95-gallon poly drum of waste. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freights contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 15:17 PM ET, XKC contacted the call center to report a spill that occurred inside of a trailer located at a customer's location, Par Electric, at 2101 Manchester Trafficway, Kansas City, MO. The spill consists of approximately 1 gallon of Aqua Balance Muriatic Acid, which released from 1 or more 1-gallon plastic jug due to other freight crushing the box containing the jugs during transit, impacting the box and the trailer floor. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1 cup from 1-gallon plastic jog of Aqua Balance Muriatic Acid product released to 1x1' area of the trailer floor and cardboard due to improper loading / load shift. The contractors overpacked the product to (1) 5-gallon metal drum and neutralized debris, cardboard, absorbents and PPE to (1) 35-gallon metal drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 11:21 AM ET, ULA contacted the call center to report a spill that was found on the dock in Santa Fe Springs, CA. The spill consists of approximately 10 ounces of Potassium Chlorate, which released from 250-pound paper bags due to the pallet containing a total of 40-to-50-pound paper bags of the same property found tipped over. The terminal stated they will have to restack the pallet and there could potentially be other bags that are leaking. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 10-ounces from 3-damaged bags of product released to trailer floor and adjacent product due to improper loading. The contractors overpacked bags of product, plastic shrink-wrap, PPE, and floor debris submerged in water to (2) 15-gallon metal drums and (1) 5-gallon metal drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2024110252
item.description:
Report E-2024110252

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-15T12:23:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-09
  • City: ANDREWS
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PETROLEUM TRANSPORTS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Driver allowed CTMV to drift onto the right shoulder of the roadway. The driver over corrected to the left, which caused the CTMV to roll onto its right side. This caused about a 2 to 3 foot cut into the tank. Approximately 3,500 gallons of unleaded gasoline spilled onto the shoulder of the roadway. The Texas Department of Public Safety responded to the scene and notified United Petroleum Transports, Inc. UPT then contracted an Environmental Clean up Service. The Environmental Clean up Service went the scene and contained the spill. It the went through the process of removing the contaminated soil and replacing it with clean soil. The final remediation was done on 11/11/2024 and report was sent to TXDEQ. Fortunately, the spill occurred in an unpopulated area so no people, homes, or business were affected.
